results.title: Edgar Wright on ‘Last Night in Soho’ and the Trap of Nostalgia
results.abstract: The “Baby Driver” director’s latest film is a thriller that explores the darker side of 1960s London and questions stories that glamorize the era.

multimedia.caption: Despite pressure to direct a sequel to “Baby Driver,” Edgar Wright opted to film “Last Night in Soho,” a story he’d been contemplating since 2012.
multimedia.copyright: Kalpesh Lathigra for The New York Times

results.title: ‘Halloween’ and the Problem With Its Sequels
results.abstract: The follow-ups took the wrong lessons from the 1978 film. But we keep giving the franchise second chances, in hopes a new one will live up to the original.

results.title: In the Company of Wes Anderson
results.abstract: What is it about the director that draws stars like Frances McDormand and Tilda Swinton again and again? There are many reasons, but the nightly feasts don’t hurt.

results.title: Loose and Boxed Ammunition Found at Scene of Alec Baldwin Shooting
results.abstract: Court papers did not specify what kind of ammunition detectives recovered from a movie set where the actor had fatally shot a cinematographer with a gun he was told did not contain live rounds.
results.byline: By Julia Jacobs and Graham Bowley

multimedia.caption: Alec Baldwin was told the gun he was rehearsing with contained no live rounds when it discharged on a movie set, killing the cinematographer. He spoke on the phone outside the Santa Fe County Sherriff’s Office on Thursday after speaking with investigators.
multimedia.copyright: Jim Weber/Santa Fe New Mexican, via Associated Press

results.title: George Butler, Bodybuilding’s Boswell in Photos and Film, Dies at 78
results.abstract: In his photographs for the book “Pumping Iron” and his documentary of the same name, Mr. Butler helped set Arnold Schwarzenegger on the road to stardom.

results.title: ‘Chess of the Wind’ Review: A Remnant of an Iran That Used to Be
results.abstract: Mohammad Reza Aslani’s 1976 film about family mendacity existed for mere days before it was banned and then lost in the ensuing tumult. Now it’s back.

multimedia.caption: Shohreh Aghdashloo in “Chess of the Wind” a 1976 film suppressed by the Iranian government and recently restored and distributed.

results.title: Wes Anderson’s Dream of France, and the Paris I Remember
results.abstract: With “The French Dispatch,” the director’s latest, yet another American artist falls under the country’s spell. The Times’s Paris bureau chief recalls when the same thing happened to him.

multimedia.caption: In “The French Dispatch,” the streets of the fictional town of Ennui-sur-Blasé are dotted with rats beneath steeply pitched zinc roofs. Not a Gallic cliché is omitted.

results.title: Gun Handed to Alec Baldwin Was Not Thoroughly Checked, Affidavit Says
results.abstract: The bullet that killed the cinematographer on the film “Rust” has been recovered, the Santa Fe County Sheriff said, and investigators believe there were more live rounds on the set.
results.byline: By Simon Romero, Julia Jacobs and Graham Bowley

multimedia.caption: Flowers left in memory of Halyna Hutchins, the cinematographer who was shot and killed on the set of the film “Rust,” outside Bonanza Creek Ranch, where it was filmed.

results.title: David DePatie, Producer Behind the Pink Panther, Dies at 91
results.abstract: He and the animator Friz Freleng created the cool feline character he called “the James Bond of the animation world.” The character’s first cartoon won an Oscar.

multimedia.caption: The producer David DePatie and the animator Friz Freleng, the forces behind the cartoon character the Pink Panther, in 1963. From left: Mr. Freleng, Mr. DePatie, Mr. Panther, the producer Harold Mirisch and Blake Edwards, director of the movie “The Pink Panther,” which used the character in its title sequence.

The producer David DePatie and the animator Friz Freleng, the forces behind the cartoon character the Pink Panther, in 1963. From left: Mr. Freleng, Mr. DePatie, Mr. Panther, the producer Harold Mirisch and Blake Edwards, director of the movie “The Pink Panther,” which used the character in its title sequence.

The producer David DePatie and the animator Friz Freleng, the forces behind the cartoon character the Pink Panther, in 1963. From left: Mr. Freleng, Mr. DePatie, Mr. Panther, the producer Harold Mirisch and Blake Edwards, director of the movie “The Pink Panther,” which used the character in its title sequence.

The producer David DePatie and the animator Friz Freleng, the forces behind the cartoon character the Pink Panther, in 1963. From left: Mr. Freleng, Mr. DePatie, Mr. Panther, the producer Harold Mirisch and Blake Edwards, director of the movie “The Pink Panther,” which used the character in its title sequence.

The producer David DePatie and the animator Friz Freleng, the forces behind the cartoon character the Pink Panther, in 1963. From left: Mr. Freleng, Mr. DePatie, Mr. Panther, the producer Harold Mirisch and Blake Edwards, director of the movie “The Pink Panther,” which used the character in its title sequence.

results.title: The film’s armorer, Hannah Gutierrez-Reed, told a detective she had checked to make sure rounds were not ‘hot.’
results.abstract: When the crew took a break for lunch, the ammunition was left out on a cart on the set, Ms. Gutierrez-Reed said.
results.byline: By Julia Jacobs and Simon Romero

results.title: Dave Halls, the assistant director, said he did not thoroughly check the gun he handed to Alec Baldwin, according to an affidavit.
results.abstract: He had declared the firearm a “cold gun,” according to court documents, indicating that it contained no live rounds and was safe to handle.
results.byline: By Graham Bowley, Julia Jacobs and Simon Romero

results.title: Criminal Charges Possible in Shooting on Alec Baldwin Set, D.A. Says
results.abstract: An inquiry into how a cinematographer was killed with a gun the actor was rehearsing with, which was not supposed to have live rounds in it, could take weeks.
results.byline: By Simon Romero, Graham Bowley and Julia Jacobs
